titleStmt.title: M52. Anon. Typescript fragment with the author's ms. corrections, unsigned and undated. 19p.
titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: M52. Anon. Typescript fragment with the author's ms. corrections, unsigned and undated. 19p. Paginated [1]-19, wanting p. 5, 14 (two p. 15).

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in sic / corr tags, wrapped in a choice element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in rs tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

div.p: Anon.

"For many centuries after Britain became an island" the orian says " "the untamed forest was king." Its mosit (moist) and
mssy (mossy) floor was hidden from heavens eye by a close drawn curtain of innumerable treetops. " On the matted bough innumerable birds snag (sang); but their song was only heard by a few skin clad hunters in the claetings (clearings). Did the desire to sing come to one of those barbarians savages because he geard (heard) the birds sing, and so rested his axe against the tree for a moment? Anyhow, the tree was felled; some sort of hut was made from its branches; and the clearing became larger; the birds f er (fewer); and the human voice sang instead. The first songs are out of door songs; spring songs; summer songs; winter songs.
Bytuene Mersh and Averil When spray biginneth to springe, The lutel foul hath hire wyl on hyre lud to synge.
Sumer is icumen in, Lhude sing cuccu
By a bank as I lay Musing myself alone, hey ho! A birdes voice Did me rejoice, Singing before the day; And me thought in her lay She said winter was past, hey ho!

They were out of door songs, because there was no comfort indoors, little light, and no books. The eye therefore was more active in in ourselves. The eye is the young sense; the sense that is attached to the body. Now and then, by chooisng (choosing) a view carefully to shut out a chimney or a bungalow, we can still see a fragment of

of what they saw-- a flat fen, reed whispering, water logged; or a down still covered with turf only. On the down is the green scar still, to mark the road along which the travellers came, past the circle where they were buried; past the stone that marks the meeting place or the burial place.

xxxxxxx sings because love and spring make him vocal or the horror of winter dark But, who listens? Somebody heard that particular song, or it would not have been written down. The singer then had his audeince (audience); but the audience was so little interested in his name that he never thought to give it.

It was the printed book with the authors name attached that was the death of . After thatThe audience was separated from the singer. After that (1478) the sing was attached to the singer. Anon gives place to James or Thomas; he lives in in a house; and he has books.

The heart of this vast proliferation of printed pages is the song. The song has the same power over the reader in the 20th century as over the hearer in the 11th. To enjoy singing, to enjoy h aring (hearing) the song, must be the deepest rooted and tough of human instincts. It is an instinct of self-preservation, for only when we put two and two together to we overcome dissolution. Two lines, two words, two bri cks (bricks) make way against oblivion. Making whatever it is gives us life; and the passion with which we seek for these creations, and attempt to make them, is of a piece with the instinct that sets us preserving our bodies from wet, or cold. But with the printing press came into existence forces that cover over the original song--books themselves and the readers of books. Could we at this this moment X ray the singers mind we shound find a nimbus surrounding the song; a st eam (stream) of influences to which so many ugly abstarct (abstract) names have been given-- influences of society; of education; of class; material; economic of econmic (economic) stress. So many are they and so obscure that we may call them nonsense names-- say , and . Nin Crot and Pully are always at their task. ?ore (More) and more [complex]

at their work--tugging, obscuring, distracting. invisble (invisible)some only visible to the writer; others only visible in [rear?] to the sufferer himself often. More and more complex they become as time passes. The song is only to be discovered ixmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmx instaneously; in a flash of recognition; some say they feel it when their beards
brsitle (bristle); others that a thrill runs down the nerves of the thigh. But the song is there still...
Waves...

That babbling child_like- stroy (story) teller, thatthe gossip at the farm door, that innocent eyed, very naked, u tful (lustful), religious singer, that great axmxmxx & new & aged great artist, Anon, died thn (then) in in 1476&. With hi (him) died something in the audience-- the They nollonger (no longer) [illeg.] filled in the payses (pauses), and joined in the chorus To follw (follow) his firtunes (fortunes) futhrer (further), we must turn to an outsider. one of those commentators who tell us so much about the
invisib (invisible) influences; about , and .. His name was
had sung his song at the back door in a jargon that was as uncouth and fxmxmxnxmxmxmxmxmus to as to ourselves; and more barbarous
Icham for wowing al forwake, Wery no water in wore An hendy hap ichable yghent; Ichot from heven it is me sent

the words were as difficult for him to spell out as for us; and more for him painful; they were [illeg.] reminders of a savagery of low b rth (birth) xmxmxmxmxmxmxx tokens of base birth, of a close savage past. In the background, mxmxmxmxxx of mind stood the Greeks and the romans; ; ; , . Those were the anicenits (ancients) who occupied the same place in Harrisons mind that the Elizabetha (Elizabethans) occupy in our minds. The readers of his time read the classics, Those were the valuable books that were chained to the sleves (shelves) in college libraries. The leanred (learned) read them; and the nobles too. "...our ancient ladies of the court" were to be found reading the holy scrpitures (scriptures) as they did their needlwork (needlework); and histories;

The great Elizabethan house is still in exist nce (existence), sxpxmx standing in its green island of [herb?] grass, separated often from the high road only by a sxmxmxx dip in the ground and a low red an old wall. It can be seen lying there, out of
proprtion (proportion) somehow, Either it is too big, or the village with its eignteen (eighteenth) ce tury (century) and tw ntieth (twentieth) century shops and villas is too small. ith (With) its congomeration (conglomeration) of roofs and chimneys, garden and chapels, it dwarfs its n ghbours (neighbours). the great Elizabethna (Elizabethan) house dwrafs (dwarfs) its neig bours () Inside all is kept as if the were expected. [illeg.] The rooms are sti ll (still) the rooms the lords and l ies (ladies) lived in. The upright Elizabethna (Elizabethan) chairs stand round the wall. Their fringes and their tapestry is not much faded. The great carved tables are polished nad lustrous. The carved [great?] chests and cupboards look brand new. Even the toys and kicknacks (knick-knacks) have survived intact :/ inlaid boxes; Here are the inlaid work boxes, and the that the Queen nahdle ([needled?]) as she sat upright on the faded pink day couch. And there, is the swollen big bel ied (bellied) lute or theorbo, on which she played, still resonant. The floor is strewn with rugs; the windows curtained with
silv r thraed (silver thread) brocades; and here are the cut glass Venice chandeliers [illeg.] which lighted this byegone company.

p.sup: & the varnished pear-shaped lute upon which the Queen once played.

div.p:
But where are the Elizabethans people? They were more ehmepral (ephemeral) than their possessions. Human Life has recded (receded) fromthis (from this) convoluted iridescent shell; with its fringes and its laces,
its elborate (elaborate) carved legs, its lops (loops) and knots, festoons and draperies upon which the spring sun of 1940
still shines so strong bright. There is a gulf between them and

ourselves. The chairs and tables are there; but the , all are untenanted. Only the furniture remains-- the lacquered, the highly painted, the ornate, the conv luted (convoluted); the chairs and tables that must have been so so hard to sit upon; If they were like their furniture, they were at once ceremonious; and crude; fantastic yet sharp, pointed, uncushioned;

The writer who hesitated conscious of his pelebian (plebian)
bith (birth) on the threshold of the great roo, , he was still unspeciali (unspecialised) undifferentiated. His eye was stimulated ; by the crimsons and the golds and the greens of the lothing (clothing); by the angles and patterns on the ceilinsg (ceilings); His ear too was stimulated and
peicked (pricked) by [words?]. Books were rea (read) aloud; each word was given sharpness and subatnce (substance) by the speaking voice. And then when the lord or lady took his lute and sang, lilt, rhytm (rhythm), melody was addd (added) to the substance and sharpness of the words. Words bubbled in his mind, old words, English words, rech (French) words, Ladtin (Latin) words. They were motlen (molten), capable of taking any shape, of reflecting nay coloure (any colours), of folliwng (following) the ones, of taking the
rhymn (rhythm) of the l te (lute). No grammar bound them tightly; nor did one society inflict its canons of good taste. Whether he ws (was) to write or to sing or to paint was an open
uetion (question). The arts were closely interwoven. For a moment there is a pause on the threshold of the great l zabethan (Elizabethan) house, when the artist sees begore (before) [illeg.] him three different paths. Shall he sing, or paint, or make poems? And then there rose up from the couryard (courtyard) the crude [voices?] tones of the mummers. It was the stagethat settled it. Had there been no stage,
no actors, might hev eben (have been) . , and our first great musician.

The writer then came to birth with difficulty in England-- the writer who is distinct from the minstrel, whose words are printed. For when familiar lettees (letters) are written in Biblical prose there must be axmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxm a barrier between what is sayable and what unsayable. a limit thus to what he can put into words writing.

He is in being , at the beginning of the sixteenth century; for the priting (printing) press has given him a name; but he is still unspecialised, undifferentiated. The artist --the person who stands otside (outside) amxmxmxmxmxmxmxmx, by some impulse desiring to observe to state rather than to take part -- is not wholly writer, wholly musician, or wholly painter. It seems possible that the great English art may not be the art of words. His eye like a painters, is alive to the clour (colour) of clothing, of country, of beats and birds; his ear, like a musicians, is stimulated by the sound of words spoken aloud His book What he wrote was read outaloud in company. "I spent most of my time" wrote in playing Glocko at Glecko,
and hearing read .. used to read to me on and Moll Neville in the
(1617-1619) Every word had its sharpnes (sharpness) weight its weight & edge given to it by the speaking voice. And then the lute and the virginals gave lilt, rhythm melody to the written words. When the fire of London was burning and the citizens loading their goods intob (into boats) noted that "Hardly one lighter or baot (boat) in three that had the goods of of a house in it, but there was a pair of virginals in it." The writers mind was full of undiffrentiated (undifferentiated) words; old words, new words; French and

Latin. No grammar bound them tightly together. They were elastic; they could be danced to and su (sung) to. But in
psp te of nthat (spite of that), they could not follw (follow) the pace of the private voice; the voice that talks intimately, briefly easily colloquially in doors.

then--- a little man with short hair, a small band, and cuffs--- standing on the threshold of the great room at was separate from the sing er; and separate from the chornicler (chronicler); and separate, in that he saw the scene with detachment from , the artists point of view, from his audience. But the book which had givn (given)
hisword (his words) aseparate existence, had brought into being a little group of readers. And that public began at once at once to exert its pressure. What is the book that will please ? What is the theme that will recommend itself to the ? What must he priase (praise)? What must he reject
W at (What) will so work upon the audience that they will procure for the poet a place, or a pension? TheseFrom this time onward there are to be the always the influences always tugging and distrting (distorting) and thwarting; as also they encourage, stimulate, draw out, help into life the writers instinct. Some are visible only to the writer himself; others only to the reader i (in) time to come. More and more complex they grow, as the book with the authors name on it goes out into a more and more

more crowded numerous, a more divided audience, to a public which [emerging from the silce (silence) of the middle ages ] desires according to its education, its poverty its to it weath (wealth), now history, now instruction, now poetry itself, and now what will make them forget the that life is ugly, or drab. As the book becomes more covered over with these influences, the thing that the writer ser set out to say becomes increasingly encu bered (encumbered). It is only to be discovered in a flash of recgnition (recognition); Some say they feel it--the original, the vital--when their beards bristle. Others that a trhill (thrill) runs down the nerves of the thigh. To disengage the song from its encumbrances becomes as time goes on, a task for the critic-- that specially equipped official who was carcely (scarcely) in existnce (existence) when emerged with his from the depths of silence.

[He had chosen his medium: & The great English art was to be, not music, not painting, but the art of words.] We call Spenser an artist, more so than the misntels (minstrels) and the song writers, because he was aware of his medoum (medium).
H ewas (He was) conscious of the possibilities and of the
limtations (limitations) of the English lang age (language). For why, a Gods name, may not we, as else the Greekes, hav the kingdome of our owne
langauge (language), and measure our accents by the sound , reserving the quantity to the verse? He applied himslef (himself) to the art.

And Like the chornicler (chronicler), the writer in order to use his medium consciously, must be aware of the past. There must be a golden age behind him; and the present must be fallen, degenerate. But, while the modern writer with a long line behind him, naturally at ackes (attacks) the generation which

which is just gone, --they but are close enough to have
dmagaed (damaged) what he is seeing partly through their eyes-- the writer in Spensers time had no definite foerebear. antagonist Spensers rdation revolt is against the lanaguge (language) not against not any particular writer, but with any particualr (particular) master of it. He has a sense of the decay of langauge (language), its cor eptuino (corruption) since the purity of , rather than a desire to destroy some actual predecssor (predecessor). He recovered the o old words, Chaucers words. Conscious perhaps of his own diffusity and sweetness, he tried to recover stiff (stiffen) his words bu the use of Chaucers words, the old words the Old English speech. But together with this sense of the past, there was present ,what we have ??? in him the sense of the future. [The sense of the future of the langauge (language) is almost extinct now] But then the writer was aware of the tumult of the Something was happening; With his acute sense of words, he must have been aware, with agitaion (agitation), with distress of what linece (license) ight (might) befall this langauge (language); He must have detected in speech, in
ballds (ballads), everyhwere (everywhere), something loosening, [fraying?], fermenting, and tried to seize; to harden; to fix the language that was abo (about) to be. before something happened
With that a joyous fellowship issewed of Minsterls making goodly merriment With wanton Bardes and Rhymers impudent
That was the voice too that was heard too in the great room.

For when we see the great Elizabthan (Elizabethan) house-- say, or -- we see the stranded relic that has e
merged (emerged) like the ribs of a wreck on the shore from thxmxmxx its surroundings. Could we see it as it is said that the airman sees a village field wxmxmxxxx xxx from the air with thexxxx scars of old roads, other villages and other houses on it. we should see the great house not alone, but connected with the village. W (We) should see a ring, an oasis in the midst of va c (vast) wild country; the raod (road) a track only; and the oasis like a fortress holding out agianst (against) the uncultivated land; stored against the everlasting siege of nature. If the enemy were man, there was armour i (in) the church. If frost or winter there was grain in the great barn. That is the connection between great house and small, between master and la ouere (labourer) that is detailed in the , and makes indeed the staple of the mediaveal (medieval) letter writing. But there was also that other connection-- the common belief. That bond between the great house and the small has faded, till it is like one of those perhaps rather greener rides stillto (still to) be found in England along which,
abntiquaries (antiquaries) say the rode to . So the scholars tell us of the roads now faded in the mind. Long before the Christains ocame (Christians came) the tree was a God; the sun was a God; Earth was God; Death was a God. the and how this anceint (ancient) worship lies beneath the other; how
With that a joyous fellowship issued Of misntrels making goodly merriment With wanton bardes and Rhymers im⅜udent (impudent)
--that voice reached Spenser too in the great room.

If the great Elizabetahn (Elizabethan) house, (, Wilton as we see it now cluttered with villas and bungalows, looks out of proportion, it is beacuse (because) the connection between the great house and the small is lost. If we could see it as it was in Spensers time we should see rxmxmxmxmxmxmxxx tracks, raying out from the great gate to the across the fields to the cooatge (cottage), to the farms, even to the hovels. there was the It was connected, if war came by the need of men. There was armour stored in the church. And ???the perpetual fight with nature made tracks from the house to the farm. A common fight linked the noble to the labourrer (labourer). That connection, the physical, between master and man is painfully and minitelt (minutely) recorded in the medieval letters. It is the staple of the whole correspon nce (correspondence)--the But there was also the other the less visible connection--the common belief. That bond between the grear (great) house and the small has been grown over, like the t ack (track) under the hill along whch the pilgrims rode to Canterbury. No one drives the e (there) now. But when Spenser came to Penshurst that rack (track) led from one house to another; pilgrims rode to Canterbury. No one drives the e (there) now. But when Spenser came to Penshurst that rack (track) led from one house to another; It led to the village green. It led to the tree: to the well. In the spring they danced round the Maypole; at midsummer they lit the bon fire on the hill; at harvest the waggons were crwoned (crowned). At Christmas the mummers acted their dumb show; the boys scame (came) wassailing. The roads led to the pagan graces, to the stones

where the old pagan Ebglish (English) had offered sacrifice. The peasants still went that way, by instinct; in summer in spring; in summer in winter. The old Gods still lay behind the Christian God. The Pagan gods were served and worshipped under cover of at the same time the Christian God. The sun was a God; the earth a goodess (goddess). Even if the old gods were los ng (losing) their names, the instinct remained when spring came, or in the cold of winter to do them h mage (homage), to placate them, to win crops, husbands, health,
detruction (destruction) of foes. The dsire (desire) to enact was coupled with the other desire--to make something useless; something unc nnected (unconnected) with the daily struggle, to bring out into the day light embodied their own
natiral (natural) love of play. To be dresded (dresseddredged) up, to emboy (embody) the beliefs that were still so strong; when so much depended on the sun; but also to emboy (embody) the insinct (instinct) of pleasure; the That sunken road, that track of ancient belief lay between the master in the great house and the peasant in the cottage. In the noble as in the peasnt (peasant) murmure (murmured) a half articulate anonumous voice murmured of old Gods and evils; The well and the tree were still haunted. As the s hpalrs ([scholars?]) ll (tell) us both noble and peasant had the same need to meboy (embody) to preresent (present) to see the instinct personfied (personified). Along the roads from town to twon (town) from one great house toanother (to another) came the mistrels (minstrels) the rhymers the jugglers the bear leaders, the makers of ballds (ballads) and actors of old lege legends. Even the King and Queen must have their misnt esl (minstrel) to give voice to the hidden instincts. Even though the actor, partly because his body is his tool partly because the lsinger (singer) and the dancer are outside the pale of daily workers and see the
pagenat (pageant) irresponsibly often mockingly, the actor was despsied (despised), they

were necessary. Just as one tolerates the person who says what we are all too proud or too self conscious to say, the minstrel was
despsied (despised) but toelerated (tolerated). Even the churchmen aware that the homage was paid not their god but the old discarded god, could not suppress the misnters (minstrels); Alll (all) they could do was to make the irrepressible
sinsinct (instinct) flow into the correct religious channel. If they could they constrained the jugglers and the bear leaders and the dancers to put off their leaves, their bells, and striped clthing (clothing) and robe them sleves (themselves) in the garb proper to the miravle (miracle) play.

This was a great bond between the great house and the
coottage (cottage). For thoug t eh (though the) great speaking frech nglish (French, English), with Latin and reek (Greek) on their to gues (tongues), might despise the jargon of the peasant, they shared the memory of what he was doing when he danced, they knew the old story he acted. Even to the King himself, it was certain that an evil sp it (spirit) dwelt in the woman in the hovel. When the were applied to her she confessed how she h d (had) gone to sea in a sieve with two hu dred (hundred) other witched (witches) and danced a reel how she had thrown a cat intot he (into the) sea and raised a stor (storm) that sunk the kin s (kings) ship. haerd (heard) the
r ymers (rhymers) and the mummenrs (mummers). He was at he (the) festival when the
And after her came jolly june arrayed All in greene leaves, as she a player were.

He had seen the man at the festival, and noted his green leaves when the had seen the masque at . It was a revival, already time had given those green leaves their mystery [illeg.]. Already the other house was being built: had jotted down in h (his) account book the ums (sums) he had paid for laths (lathes) and nails and timber to build a play house. He had given so much for painting the theatre. He

distance he sees them pictriallly (pictorally); grouped, like the
figur s (figures) in a fresco,with the flowers growing at their feet, behind them marble pillars, trees with bright birds, and the libbard and the lion couching (couchant) or rampamt (rampant). There is no tension; no direction but always movement, as the metre flings its curve of sound that, like a wave, breaks always on the same pace (place). Folded in this intation (incantation) we drwose (drowse)and sleep yet always start awake. For the T [illeg.] is illuminated.
<Still there is something anonymous about . He cannot confine emotions within one person. He must externalise and symbolise.

But Spenser standing on the threshold of the great room is half in shdow (shadow), half in light. He is still anonymous in that he cannot confine emotions within one person. He must symbolise; exteriorise. If a man is jealous, he canno (cannot) show it save by making a symbol of jealousy. He must
Jealusy (Jealousy) becomes The feelings of men and women must be
symblised (symbolised) and given a body outside th ir (their) own. He ignores
hims lf (himself), the individual. Yet at the same time, forces are at work that make him conscious of himself, the man who is separate from the audeince (audience), who is giving the wolrd (world) something of himself, whois (who is) conscious of the worlds scron (scorn) and neglect of what he gives. He is aware of his art as was not, nor , nor . His is no longer a wandering voice, but the voice of a man practising an art, and asking for recognition.
Had the poet remained in the great room, profferig (proffering) his book to the little group of readers, English poetry

might hav (have) rxmxmxmxxx a book read aloud; a recollection; something read by the leisured listening in the great room to some one reading aloud. But there was the other voice the voice at the back door, the voice that heard himself--- ...of minstrels making goodly merriment With wanton bardes and rhymers impudent.

Spenser ims lf (himself) had heard it. H h (He had) been, it is said, at the pageant at when to amuse the Queen, an old story was staged. And Soenser (Spenser) noted the player dressed in green leaves. The nobles it seems, had a great love of txxxx those r de (rude) voices. Ironically enoug (enough) the preacher who was for banihsing (banishing) and such ancient supersttions (superstitions) was himself forging the very weapon that gave the old misntersl (minstrels) their le a new lease of life When said in English at the
beginng (beginning) and end of his sermon he was tting (putting) English into high places. He was rescuing it from the back door. He was teaching the nobles how to r ad (read) English; he was making that alliance between the peasant and the noble which was necssary (necessary), should all classes meet together at the at the at the .

When the Queen and the poet togteher (together) saw the old
paganet (pageant) with the players still wearing green levaes (leaves) at Kenilworth, the builders of the new theatre were ordering nails, planks, the xmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxxx first theate (theatre) was being built, at , among the stews, When the flag flew, the poor and the rich came together, in the open air,
and on that stage, without any scenery, but richly dressed, the old mummers were to act not Robin Hood, not , not play but , , , , and .
